abstract.para: Today, many people use computers with a graphical user interface (GUI) like &gnome;. Although they offer lots of features, their use is limited when it comes to the execution of automated tasks. Shells are a good addition to GUIs and this chapter gives you an overview of some aspects of shells, in this case Bash.

sect1.title: What is The Shell?
sect1.para: Traditionally, the shell is Bash (Bourne again Shell). When this chapter speaks about the shell it means Bash. There are actually more available shells than Bash (ash, csh, ksh, zsh, …), each employing different features and characteristics. If you need further information about other shells, search for shell in &yast;.

sect2.title: Knowing the Bash Configuration Files
sect2.para: A shell can be invoked as an:

formalpara.title: Interactive login shell
formalpara.para: This is used when logging in to a machine, invoking Bash with the --login option or when logging in to a remote machine with SSH.

formalpara.title: Ordinary interactive shell
formalpara.para: This is normally the case when starting xterm, konsole, gnome-terminal or similar tools.

formalpara.title: Non-interactive shell
formalpara.para: This is used when invoking a shell script at the command line.

sect1.title: Redirecting Command Events
sect1.para: Each command can use three channels, either for input or output:

formalpara.title: Standard Output
formalpara.para: This is the default output channel. Whenever a command prints something, it uses the standard output channel.

formalpara.title: Standard Input
formalpara.para: If a command needs input from users or other commands, it uses this channel.

formalpara.title: Standard Error
formalpara.para: Commands use this channel for error reporting.

sect1.title: Working with Common Flow Constructs
sect1.para: To control the flow of your script, a shell has while, if, for and case constructs.

sect2.title: The if Control Command
sect2.para: The if command is used to check expressions. For example, the following code tests whether the current user is Tux:
sect2.screen: if test $USER = "tux"; then echo "Hello Tux." else echo "You are not Tux." fi
sect2.para: The test expression can be as complex or simple as possible. The following expression checks if the file foo.txt exists:
sect2.screen: if test -e /tmp/foo.txt ; then echo "Found foo.txt" fi
sect2.para: The test expression can also be abbreviated in angled brackets:

sect2.title: Creating Loops with the for Command
sect2.para: The for loop allows you to execute commands to a list of entries. For example, the following code prints some information about PNG files in the current directory:
sect2.screen: for i in *.png; do ls -l $i done
